propositions.text: The narrator is haunted by the death of Wang Quansheng, especially the fact that Wang Quansheng's corpse did not decay and appeared at the entrance of Nangong.
Wang Quansheng's death occurred in the narrator's room, and the narrator disposed of the body using a tricycle.
The narrator fears the police will investigate the circumstances of Wang Quansheng's death and implicate him.
The narrator experiences recurring nightmares and sleep disturbances after returning from the Guangchuan Royal Tomb.
The narrator wakes up to find a figure squatting in the corner of his room.
The figure turns out to be Wang Quansheng, appearing as a corpse with a distorted neck and long fingernails.
The narrator experiences a terrifying encounter and attempts to escape.
The narrator realizes the encounter was a nightmare, but the fear and anxiety persist.
The narrator finds his blanket soaked in sweat.
Upon waking again, the narrator sees a figure in the corner, which turns out to be his companion, 'Shaoye'.
Shaoye explains he was in the room to catch mice.
The narrator recounts his nightmare about Wang Quansheng to Shaoye.
The narrator and Shaoye join other companions for breakfast.
They learn that the treasures they recovered from the Guangchuan Royal Tomb are now in police custody.
Huang Zhihua, a police official, urgently approaches the narrator and his companions.
Huang Zhihua informs them that Wang Quansheng's corpse has gone missing from the morgue.
This news intensifies the narrator's fear and anxiety, linking it to his nightmares.
Huang Zhihua reveals that a murder has occurred at the guesthouse owned by Shaoye's family, and Wang Quansheng's corpse was found at the crime scene.
The narrator deduces that Wang Quansheng might have gone to the guesthouse to confront him.
The narrator, Shaoye, and Yatou accompany Huang Zhihua to the guesthouse.
The guesthouse room where Wang Quansheng died previously is now the scene of a new murder.
The new victim's death is described as peculiar, with a smile on his face and bruises on his neck, resembling the death of another acquaintance, Dan Jun.
Huang Zhihua examines Wang Quansheng's corpse and notes it doesn't appear fresh.
The narrator internally curses the police for not handling the case of Wang Quansheng's corpse properly.
The investigation at the crime scene yields no signs of forced entry.
Huang Zhihua convenes a meeting with the narrator, Shaoye, and Yatou.
Huang Zhihua asks about Wang Quansheng's prior visit to Taiyuan and his interaction with them.
An old man, referred to as 'Nanpazi', states that Wang Quansheng has been dead for at least six months and that the recently deceased victim was a local.
The old man reveals that 'Zhong Shi' (Middle Corpse) has come alive.
This statement causes the narrator to fall off his chair in shock.
The narrator confesses to disposing of Wang Quansheng's body six months prior, admitting to buying bronze artifacts from him.
Huang Zhihua proposes that the narrator, Shaoye, and Yatou assist in the investigation.
Huang Zhihua offers the narrator leniency in exchange for their cooperation.
Yatou and Shaoye agree to cooperate.
The narrator reflects on the curse of the dragon coffin and the phenomenon of corpses exhibiting 'Shi Bian' (corpse transformation).
He considers the activation of 'Zhong Shi' and 'Xia Shi' (Lower Corpse).
The old man suggests that the newly deceased victim's body must be cremated quickly to prevent further issues.
He also proposes a plan to deal with Wang Quansheng's corpse.
The narrator, Shaoye, and Yatou discuss their predicament.
The old man visits the narrator's room and hints at a connection to the 'Dragon Coffin' in the Yellow River.
He proposes that the narrator must go to the 'Wind Eye of Yingkunlun' to find 'Jinlou Sunu' to break the curse.
The old man suggests that treasure might be found there, offering the narrator a chance to keep some of it.
Yatou agrees to accompany the narrator to Yingkunlun.
The old man gives Yatou a 'Xiangsi Jade Bracelet' as a gift.
Hu Lai, the old man's apprentice, rushes in with news of an emergency involving a 'God of Wealth' that nearly injured 'Uncle Luo'.
The narrator realizes 'God of Wealth' refers to a zombie, and Hu Lai reveals it is Wang Quansheng.
The old man is angry, blaming the narrator for the situation with Wang Quansheng's corpse retaining a soul and spirit, which could lead to it becoming a ghost if cremated.

concepts.name: Wang Quansheng
concepts.context: The deceased individual whose corpse is central to the plot, appearing as a disturbing figure and a source of fear and mystery.

concepts.name: Narrator (Xu Sanqing)
concepts.context: The protagonist, recounting the events and experiencing nightmares and fear related to Wang Quansheng's death and the supernatural occurrences.

concepts.name: Shaoye
concepts.context: The narrator's companion, who provides support and humor, and is involved in the unfolding mystery.

concepts.name: Yatou
concepts.context: A female companion who is also involved in the investigation and shows loyalty to the narrator.

concepts.name: Huang Zhihua
concepts.context: A police official investigating the cases, who enlists the narrator and his friends for help.

concepts.name: Old Man (Nanpazi)
concepts.context: A mysterious elder, likely an archaeologist or grave robber, who possesses knowledge of ancient lore and supernatural phenomena.

concepts.name: Dragon Coffin
concepts.context: A significant artifact associated with a curse that affects those who come into contact with it.

concepts.name: Guangchuan Royal Tomb
concepts.context: A location the characters visited, from which they recovered artifacts and which seems connected to the supernatural events.

concepts.name: Corpse Transformation (Shi Bian)
concepts.context: The phenomenon where a dead body exhibits unnatural movement or behavior, a recurring theme.

concepts.name: Zhong Shi (Middle Corpse)
concepts.context: A supernatural state of a corpse, seemingly activated in Wang Quansheng's case.

concepts.name: Yingkunlun
concepts.context: A location mentioned as a potential place to find a solution to the Dragon Coffin curse.

concepts.name: Jinlou Sunu
concepts.context: A legendary entity or object believed to be buried in Yingkunlun, potentially key to breaking the curse.

concepts.name: Hu Lai
concepts.context: The old man's apprentice, who brings urgent news.

concepts.name: Uncle Luo
concepts.context: A person mentioned in relation to an incident with a zombie.

concepts.name: Zombie
concepts.context: Referred to as 'God of Wealth' and 'Cai Shen', a reanimated corpse.

concepts.name: Ghost
concepts.context: A potential outcome for Wang Quansheng's soul if his corpse is mishandled.

concepts.name: Bronze Artifacts
concepts.context: Items purchased from Wang Quansheng, linking the narrator to him.

concepts.name: Guesthouse
concepts.context: A location owned by Shaoye's family, where a murder occurs.

concepts.name: Dan Jun
concepts.context: An acquaintance whose death is compared to the new victim's death.

concepts.name: Xiangsi Jade Bracelet
concepts.context: A gift from the old man to Yatou, described as valuable.

concepts.name: Liu Qu
concepts.context: The previous owner of the Guangchuan Royal Tomb, whose epitaph is mentioned.

concepts.name: Three Emperors and Five Emperors
concepts.context: Ancient Chinese mythological figures, mentioned in relation to 'Jinlou Sunu'.

hierarchy.structure: The document follows a chronological narrative, beginning with the protagonist's nightmares and anxieties, escalating to the discovery of a murder and the disappearance of a corpse, and culminating in the proposal of a dangerous expedition to resolve the supernatural curse. It is structured as a first-person account of unfolding events and the protagonist's internal struggles.
